A inspiring tale that provokes a conversation on boyhood, masculinity, and the intimate nuance between fathers and sons. While at times predictable and likely because of the source material, Director Andrew Kightlinger fuses adventure, myth, and a rocky (pun intended) father son dynamic to tell a compelling, touching story that pits innocent angst against patriarchal pride that’s timely today to remind us just how important the balance between work and family truly is. 

Moreover, the film is worth a watch for its technical elements as well, which prove that $5M indie dramas still have a place against the saturated visual effect spectacle. Cinematography feels real, especially at the treacherous summit, which effectively highlights that you don’t need high budget VFX to create emotional anchoring. 

Lastly, the indigenous elements while interesting and certainly central to the film’s catalyst moment could have been further explored throughout the film a bit more to build more suspense and heighten the stakes even further. Despite this, Kightlinger proves his empathic and collaborative approach to filmmaking that’s so badly needed for our American film industry.

“Lost on a Mountain in Maine” tells the remarkable true story and deserves to be among the classic American coming-of-age films, right alongside “Stand By Me.”  Luke David Blumm does a fantastic job portraying the complex experience of 12 year-old Donn Fendler lost alone in the deep wilderness of Mount Katahdin.  Donn emerges nine days later a different person, and no longer the boy he was. It is to the director’s great credit that Donn’s growth feels organic and unforced; the transformation is subtle, believable, and beautifully embodied by Blumm, whose performance is riveting.  And it is not only young Donn who is changed; the adults in his life, and his relationships with them, are also transformed.  In particular, Donn’s father’s (Paul Sparks) love for his sons mellows from a tough-love inspired by life during the Great Depression, to an unconditional love and appreciation of both his child’s vulnerability, and undeniable grit.  This will be a great movie to watch over and over as a family, as a holiday tradition, and as a reminder of the strength of children and of love.
Wonderful movie about a Maine family and one boys adventure that thankfully ended well!

I'm a Mainer, so I've heard this story many times as it is a part of most kids' school curriculum growing up. But this film isn't primarily interested in the survival aspect of Donn's story. What it seems to truly be after is painting a wonderful and complicated image of a father and son relationship. While this means that, in the end, you will be drawn to tears, it also means that this movie feels much slower that it should have been. Better pacing with a greater urgency would have propelled this movie into five star status. However, it is absolutely beautifully shot, well acted, and has a very moving, if subdued score. In the end, Donn's story is done a tremendous amount of justice, and I am glad to know that his tale put to film will inspire millions of kids outside of our great state. Read the book!
